MARIA BARTIROMO: Hello ladies, good morning to you. Thanks so much we'll see you in a little while. Good morning everybody, thanks for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Wednesday, it is Wednesday March 28th. Your top stories right now, 6 A.M. on the East Coast. Technology taking it's toll, stocks stumble yesterday, weighed down by major technology names. Facing concerns over new regulatory scrutiny. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 344 points, down one and a half percent. Along the top loser's yesterday, Facebook, Alphabet and Apple which all turned negative for the year.

The news coming as Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agrees to testify before lawmakers on Capital Hill. Facebook down another 5 percent. Future this morning, looking like this, we're looking at weakness at the trading this morning. Dow industrial set to open down about 50 points. NASDAQ also down 45 points right now. Investors are watching for the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP that is due out at 8:30 A.M. eastern. We are expecting growth of two point seven percent. That is the economist estimate.

For Europe this morning right across the board, take a look at the European embassy's(ph) FT 100 down two thirds of one percent and the CAC cost(ph) and the DAX index both down better than 1 percent right now. In Asia over night, similar stories, steep declines across the board. Worse performers is Hong Kong, HANG SENG index down two and a half percent. The global sell off coming amid a possible crack down. Speculation is mounting that the White House is considering regulating Chinese investments in technology companies. Senator Lindsey Graham waiting on taking that action against China.

LINDSEY GRAHAM: They steal everything you bring to China, they manipulate the currency, they dump steal in a below value into the world economy and Trump said during the campaign he was going to push back. He has. And if the French and the Germans were smart, they would join President Trump to change Chinese business practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Then major implications for the sector and the markets coming up this morning. The trade deal secured, President Trump making moves, reaching an agreement with South Korea, his first deal since taking office. We are breaking down the deal as the commander in chief makes good on yet another campaign promise. And new problems to report for Tesla. The details as the National Transportation Safety Board investigates another fatal crash. The stock down (ph) another two percent this morning.

Too slow. FBI Directory Christopher Wray says he will double the number of personnel assigned to reviewing the GOP demanding documents in the investigation of the Clinton e-mail investigation, FBI abuse and the firing of Andrew McCabe. We'll tell you what's next after that subpoena got things moving. And then talk about a d'oh-nut. Springfield coming to Krispy Kreme with Simpsons themed pastries.

All that coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it this (ph) Fox Business hour is Dagen McDowell, Benchmark managing partner Kevin Kelly and the Wall Street Journal's editorial board member, Fox News contributor Mary Kissel.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, JOURNALIST, FOX BUSINESS NEWS: D'oh.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I knew she was going to do that. That's good. Thank you. Thank you so much.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: You didn't do too bad a job yourself.

BARTIROMO: OK. Hey, welcome back from -- from the wedding.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you very much. I missed you guys, but --

BARTIROMO: We missed you. Yes.

KELLY: Yes, but it worked out. I got to tear up the dance floor, you know. It was -- it was perfect.

BARTIROMO: How's the missus?

KELLY: She's doing exceptionally well. She's --

BARTIROMO: Congratulations.

KELLY: Yes. Yes. It's -- this is -- it's called perseverance, 12 years a love story in the making. I mean, it --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: 12 years.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes. Wow (ph).

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wow.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, so -- so --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He's really in love.

BARTIROMO: She's patient. She's a keeper.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, she's great.

BARTIROMO: A lot on the table this morning to discuss, you guys. We got trade, we got the market sell-off. Lot of uncertainty over there.

MARY KISSEL, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Yes, lot of uncertainty and a lot of fake news about this trade deal, too, Maria. I hope we're going to get into that. It's not exactly I think what the White House is selling.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

KISSEL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll talk about that.

MCDOWELL: And then also questions about Facebook going forward, it's profitability, how much is it worth. It's really hard to put a number on it. If you have users leaving or spending less time on the service and advertisers turning their back on Facebook, potentially. Again, that's a big question mark and it's certainly weighing on the broad market.

BARTIROMO: This is -- this is the real first test that we've seen for this company in terms -- you're right, valuation, but also the sustainability, if people are worried about user data.

KELLY: They -- they really --

MCDOWELL: Mark -- Mark -- Mark Zuckerberg didn't invent anything. We kept playing that sound bite from Steve Jobs. He didn't invent anything, just preyed on our desire to be liked. It's a -- it's an advertising vehicle. He just did a better job than Classmates and Tripod and Geocities. I date myself, but thank god I am close to 50, because I actually remember a lot of these companies that tried to do what Facebook did.

It's at 2 billion users. How much bigger can it get?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: If (ph) those people spend less time on that service, those -- those earnings are going to be a lot lower than people think.

BARTIROMO: And boy, did investors react yesterday. That is our top story right now, the technology sector taking a beating. A steep sell-off in tech stocks yesterday pulled U.S. markets sharply lower with the DOW closing down nearly 400-points. One day after the indices posted their best day in more than two years. Technology stock has come under pressure amid concerns over increased government scrutiny in the wake of privacy questions surrounding Facebook.

All this coming amid speculation that the Trump administration is considering a crackdown on Chinese investments in U.S. technologies by using a law reserved for national emergencies. Joining us now to weigh in is director of defense studies at the Center for National Interest and the executive editor of National Interest Magazine, Harry Kazianis. Good to see you, Harry. Thanks very much for joining us.

HARRY KAZIANIS, DIRECTOR OF DEFENSE STUDIES, CENTER FOR NATIONAL INTEREST: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So let's start first with the crackdown on Chinese investments in technology. We know that China has participated in 10 percent off venture deals in the U.S. in the last five years. Your take on what could happen in terms of China investing in U.S. companies.

KAZIANIS: Maria, I think there being some sort of restrictions is a very practical and an important step. I think if we look at the history of Chinese actions, really over the last 10 years and things they've done to the United States, not just economic but geopolitical, there had to be some restrictions. You know, being in the defense sector, looking at this from that perspective, we look at some of the things the Chinese done in terms of stealing a lot of our defense intellectual property.

They've hacked in and stolen our aircraft carrier designs, the V-22 Osprey, the F-35, which is a trillion dollar defense program. So when you look at it from that perspective, there has to be some restrictions. And then we talk about the technology of the future, things like 5G, A.I. If Chinese companies were to come in and essentially, you know, buy parts of U.S. companies or get into joint ventures and then take that technology, we're essentially giving away our economic future to China. And I think that would be a big mistake.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, I know that we have CFIUS, Mary, and that really does regulate the -- whether or not we should see ownership of American companies. But at the same time, China has such strict situations with regard to American investing there. And we don't have anything like that.

KISSEL: No, I mean look, our tariff barriers are very low compared to China. And China also has a lot of barriers that are not set in stone or formalized, right? They -- they say well, you know, if you come here and you really want to get in, you have to give us 51 percent control and we to have a communist party member on your board in China, things like that.

So Harry's absolutely right. There are a lot of problems here. Harry, my question to you is what is strategic? You know, I understand that we don't want investment in dual use technologies, defense, certain telecommunication industries, but where else does this go? Does it go to energy companies? I mean, what's the limit here?

KAZIANIS: I think the thing that I worry about most, Mary, is technologies of the future. Like I was saying, 5G could be a revolutionary technology. I mean, most of us at home are getting -- you know, on our internet speeds, about 100, 150 megs per second. That is the speeds of -- of 5G over cellular networks. That could be revolutionary in terms of self driving cars, medical devices.

And in terms of, you know, strategy and -- and overall geopolitics and intelligence, if the Chinese were to gain footholds in those arenas, the amount of intelligence they could gather would be astronomical. Now, I don't want to sound like I'm panicking over, you know, what the Chinese can do in terms of intelligence capabilities, but I think we have some very real concerns when you combine that, in terms of all of the geopolitical things the Chinese have done over 10 years.

So I think it's good to be cautious, I think it's something that we have to do. But we have to remember, the U.S. China relationship is changing, really since the fall of the Soviet Union in1991. This relationship was begging to be changed. I mean, one of the reasons why America and China actually came together in the first place is because of the Soviet Union.

When the Soviet Union collapsed, there was always going to be some sort of inevitable change, but it was always economics that brought us together. Now it's actually --

BARTIROMO: Just want to (ph) point out, Kevin, one -- one thing that Devin Nunes told me on Sunday is not only are we dealing with these economic issues with China, but right now, they're buying up a lot of infrastructure across the world. They're investing in these countries and then getting a sealine position and setting up military bases right there. This is another thing that this administration is watching over (ph).

KELLY: Yes, especially in Africa, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

KELLY: In -- in -- in Djibouti. And I think one of the --

BARTIROMO: Right.

KELLY: -- important things to note is that China is going to get this 5G technology whether we like it or not, right? And one of the -- the things this administration has done is block the Broadcom deal with Qualcomm. The issue actually has to do with will we have that infrastructure, that technology? Are we going to have access to it in times of national defense? And I think that's the biggest -- biggest question.

If -- if we don't have access to it and only the Chinese do, if they're scooping up U.S. companies, that's the biggest issue. But I think the -- I think one of the things we're tiptoeing around is North Korea. I mean, China is completely enabling North Korea and a lot of their weaponized attacks across the world, whether it's in South Korea, here.

So the only way North Korea survives and thrives is through China. Now, do you think that's one of the biggest conflicts of interest that we're having right now with China and their technology? Harry?

KAZIANI: I do. I do. And I -- and I think the -- the point on North Korea is so key here. I mean, no wonder the -- you know -- Kim Jung-un is going to, you know, meet with Xi Jinping so early, in terms of having multiple different summits and whatnot. And I think when we talk about issues on the Korean Peninsula and how this all comes to play, I think it's extremely important for the United States to continue making sure that we apply maximum pressure on both of those countries.

Because there's a relationship where essentially North Korea feeds off China, but China also feeds off North Korea. And I think as long as we're ensuring that pressure on both sides is being maintained, I think that's the smartest way to go. So I -- I think all of these situations we're talking about, the recalibrating of the U.S. China relationship, North Korea, it's all one big pot that we have to worry about.

MCDOWELL: We always talk about the big picture in terms of the U.S. and China and China's investment in technologies. There's a story in the Wall Street Journal that pinpoints how it does effect mama and daddy, if you will, in -- in rural parts of America.

And a lot of smaller telecomm companies have relied on gear made by Huawei, the bigger company since 2012 because there was a fear -- there was a congressional report done -- there was a fear that China would exploit that technology being in the United States in order to spy or even hack into our data networks.

But smaller telecomm companies have relied on that very gear because it's cheaper. And there was an -- the FCC put out a proposal on Monday that might -- that will likely restrict these smaller companies drawing on this $8.5 billion government-run fund to build out these rural networks. So again, there are broad implications for these rules that are sent out of Washington.

BARTIROMO: And -- and the administration is watching each of these nuances. Meanwhile, we've got to talk about this. The state media has reported -- the Chinese state new media reporting that North Korean leader Kim Jong-un did in fact make a surprise visit to Beijing to meet with President Xi Jinping.

The North Korean leader reportedly told his Chinese counterpart that Pyongyang is committed to denuclearization, and is willing to talk to U.S. officials. President Trump just tweeted about this moments ago, want to get this tweet out right away.

Here's what the president just said, for years and through many administrations, everyone said that peace and the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula was not even a small possibility.

Now there is a good chance that Kim Jong-un will do what is right for his people and for humanity. Look forward to our meeting. And of course, we know that the president is planning on meeting the head of the North Korea in may, Harry, do you -- do we know what Kim Jong-un would want in exchange for potentially giving up his nuclear weapons?

Do we believe that he even would consider such a thing?

KAZIANIS: Well Maria, that's the golden question in this whole situation. What does Kim Jong-un want? I think at a bare minimum, he's going to want some sort of peace treaty to formally end the Korean War, some sort of diplomatic recognition by the United States, potentially as much as hundreds of billions of dollars in economic assistance.

That might be one of the reasons he actually went to China. He -- he is going to demand a lot, but we're also going to demand a lot. We're going to need to have really tough inspections to go in and make sure the North Koreans are actually living up to the deal.

But (ph) even gets worse, I mean do they give up their chemical weapons or missiles? We have a lot of questions this morning and not a lot of answers.

BARTIROMO: Mary Kissel, you're not buying it, and you're -- and you're also not buying this first major trade deal with South Korea. We spoke --

KISSEL: No, but just first -- first on this North Korea meeting, Kim Jong- un's goal here, Maria, is to combine the two Koreas and to have North Korea run South Korea, that's the goal.

He wants to eject U.S. troops from the Korean Peninsula, he is never going to voluntarily give up his nuclear program. The only way that North Korea talking to China is a good thing is if China is brokering a deal to take Kim Jong-un and put him into exile in Monaco or some prison somewhere in the world.

That's the only way that that's going to be a good -- a good meeting.

BARTIROMO: I just think that China reinserted itself real quick on this deal, why aren't you buying this up (ph) (inaudible).

KISSEL: So Trump administration says that this is great for free trade, this is not market opening, this is called manage trade. This is called managed trade, this is where we're going back to the 1980's where we're trying to set quotas and limits on how certain goods move between countries.

It's not market opening, it -- it's not good for trade, it rewards certain industries, in fact, I'd say it's a little bit of a swamp coming back to Washington.

BARTIROMO: Wow, all right, we'll keep watching that. Harry, great to have you this morning, thanks so much for your insights.

KAZIANIA: Thanks for having me, guys.

BARTIROMO: Harry Kazianis there, coming up the NTSB launching a probe into a fatal Tesla crash, whether the automated driving system is to blame. The impact on the brand, the company, the stock, which had another tough day yesterday, this morning it is down again.

The FBI and the GOP leaders need to agree on one thing, the response to demands to turn over documents on alleged abuses at the agency has gone way too slow. Find out how the director is picking up the pace after that subpoena from Bob Goodlatte, back in a moment.

(COMMERICAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. President Trump is tweeting this morning. Guess (ph) what he just sent out, the second amendment will never be repealed, as much as democrats would like to see this happen and despite the words yesterday of former Supreme Court Justice Stevens, no way.

We need more republicans in 2018 and must always hold the Supreme Court. Meanwhile there's this, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg decides to testify before Congress.

Cheryl Casone with the details now, finally he says he's going to do it.

CHERYL CASONE, ANCHOR: Yes, I mean we were kind of wondering what he was going to do. Zuckerberg is now expected to face pretty tough questions about the companies handling of user data.

This entire controversy started after British political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica -- excuse me -- allegedly misused the personal data of 50 million Facebook users. So Facebook stock actually dropped nearly five percent yesterday over worries about more regulation, stocks down 15 percent for the month of March.

This makes it the worst month for this stock since July of 2012. This morning, again, stock to watch is down on the pre-market, it's come back a little bit, but is down more than half a percent.

We should say that it -- he is still declining to talk to British lawmakers. Maria, so he'll talk to those here in the United States. (Inaudible) investigators are looking into another fatal crash involving the Tesla that happened last Friday in California.

National Transportations Safety Board says it not clear if the car's autopilot was on at the time. The Model X caught fire after it hit a highway barrier and was struck by two other vehicles, one man died as a result of this crash.

Tesla stocks plunged eight percent yesterday, we should say, and shares are lower in the pre-market, nearly two percent to the downside right now. Well let's stay in the car theme, because Uber is putting the breaks on its driverless car testing in California.

They are temporarily suspending all testing after a woman was killed by one of its cars while crossing the street in Tempe, Arizona. Cameras show the safety driver, who we later found out was a convicted felon, looking down, away from the road at the time of the crash.

This is the video, Uber says it will not renew its permit in California to test the vehicles for the foreseeable future. Also in California, Uber reaching a $10 million settlement in a discrimination lawsuit.

Two women engineers accused Uber of gender and racial discrimination, they claimed that Uber's employee ranking system favors men and white or Asian employees. According to filing, the settlement compensates for financial and emotional harm, to about 285 women and 135 men of color.

And I'm going to leave you with this, something a little brighter, in an ode to Homer Simpson, we love him, Krispy Kreme is releasing a real life version of Homer's favorite donut.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So you like donuts? Well have all of the (ph) donuts in the world.

(LAUGHTER)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

That's a lot of donuts. The Simpson's donut is a glazed donut then they dip it in strawberry flavored white chocolate truffle, that's how it's iced, and then there's rainbow sprinkles on top.

You can't get them in the U.S., this is very frustrating, they're only available in Australia. Thanks a lot Krispy Kreme.

BARTIROMO: So I guess that means you didn't bring any?

CASONE: Well you know I would have (inaudible) get my hands on them.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Cheryl. The president just tweeted this, we want to get this out here, he says this, received message last night from Xi Jingping of China that his meeting with Kim Jong-un went very well and that Kim looks forward to his meeting with me.

In the mean time, and unfortunately, maximum sanctions and pressure must be maintained at all costs. The president just -- it's important to not that John Bolton, now the -- his national security advisor, was behind the -- the Bush administration effort to basically intervene and prevent the transfer of weapons material, the anti-proliferation measures that were put in place during the Bush administration, so (inaudible) ...

(CROSSTALK)

KISSEL: Yes, proliferation security initiative very good, and he also saw appeasement up close, spoke out very strongly against it during the Bush years.

BARTIROMO: Very important.

McDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right (ph), we'll keep following that. We'll take a break.

When we come back, a New York City Firefighter is laid to rest yesterday after being killed on a movie set.

Meanwhile, actor Edward Norton's production company is facing a multi- million dollar suit because of that blaze.

Plus, Rosanne reboot getting political. The NBC show taking a page from real life with major support for the president.

Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right, the FBI is finally responding to Bob Goodlatte's subpoena. He's doubling up.

FBI Director Christopher Wray is doubling the number of personnel assigned to responding to the House subpoena for documents relating to the ongoing Hilary Clinton investigation, the FBI abuse controversy and the FBI's internal recommendation to fire former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe.

This comes after House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte issued a subpoena for those documents. He told me he would on Sunday Morning Futures - about the slow response, and he asked about the next move, as I asked him about the subpoena.

He issued the judicial proceeding days later.

(VIDEO BEGINS)

BOB GOODLATTE, REPRESENTATIVE, REPUBLICAN: The department and the Bureau have been slow - I would say, now, very slow - in getting them to us.

The last time I was on your program, I expressed confidence that we would have those documents forthcoming, and here we are several weeks later, still don't have them, so this is coming to a head.

(VIDEO ENDS)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is former Special Assistant to President Trump, former Press Secretary to Vice President Pence, and today (ph) RNC consultant Mark Lauder (ph). Mark, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

MARC LOTTER, RNC CONSULTANT: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Do you think they're going to get these documents? I mean it's absolutely extraordinary to me that they requested 1.2 million documents, and they've only been given 3,000.

LOTTER: I do think they'll get the documents. It's an enormous request, and having worked for many different government agencies, these take a lot of time and a lot of manpower to get through.

But I think it's also very good that the - that the FBI recognizes the problem, and they're dealing with it by doubling the staff.

I mean this is a public relations nightmare for the FBI. Not only are they being questioned in terms of how they've handled the investigations, how they've handled the various activities, now they're being questioned about the process. So eliminate the process questions, and let's get to the bottom of it.

BARTIROMO: Well is it just a P.R. nightmare, or is it something more? I mean the fact is, is there's been stonewalling for almost a year.

And not only that, but we now know because of these text message, of the bias at the top of the FBI, and how they used kid gloves with the Hillary Clinton investigation, but we're very happy to investigate Donald Trump.

So I mean, I think it might be more than just P.R.

LOTTER: Well, it is more than that, in terms of the actual underlying issues, and it's something that Director Wray has talked about getting to the bottom of, and it's something that Congress definitely wants to.

But having to fight a battle over process is not good for the FBI, so that's - it's a (ph) good sign that Director Wray has moved in this direction, to double the amount of people that are dealing with these requests.

BARTIROMO: Let's move on to the speculation around the Speaker of the House, Paul Ryan. A (ph) Nevada Republican Congressman told a local journalist this week he heard through the grapevine that House Speaker Paul Ryan is on his way out.

Reports say majority whip (ph) Steve Scalise or House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy could replace him.

Here's what Speaker Ryan told me when I asked him about his future plans just last month.

(VIDEO BEGINS)

BARTIROMO: Are you going to stick around in order to see the fruits of your labor ...

PAUL RYAN, SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: I can't really answer that question (ph).

BARTIROMO: ... because the rumblings are you're going to hopefully keep the House, as you just said, but then ...

RYAN: Yes, no, I feel good about - I really think we're going to keep the House.

BARTIROMO: ... resign and step down after November?

RYAN: Look, my wife and I have that conversation in the spring of every election year. We haven't had that yet. We'll figure it out then.

(VIDEO ENDS)

BARTIROMO: Paul Ryan has dismissed any plans to step down. Do you think we see somebody else holding the gavel soon?

LOTTER: No, I don't. I think the Speaker does - he - we just passed historic tax cuts with the President, they've got a big agenda, and I know that the Speaker has a number of items on his plate that he still wants to get to.

He's raising money left and right for republicans running for congress and to keep the majority. I think you'll see him be a Speaker again next year.

BARTIROMO: I wonder what happens. I mean, I - what I've heard was the inside is that eventually he will step down, but not before the mid-terms. What do you think, Mary?

KISSEL: Well, I don't know. I'm curious to see if they're going to try for another tax bill, try to make the personal income tax cuts permanent.

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: ... thing was health care, though, and that - and that's what he took issue on and said here, is he was so furious that the senate wouldn't back their plans for health care.

So he's like, hey, we've done our job on the house side, and he repeatedly said that, and he took - he took offense to John McCain coming in and actually destroying it in the 12th hour.

(CROSSTALK)

McDOWELL: And passing that stupid spending bill. That basically took making the individual tax cuts permanent - took that off the table.

BARTIROMO: You think so?

McDOWELL: In my opion.

(CROSSTALK)

KISSEL: He cares about the party, though. I'm not sure he'd want to make it look like chaos right before the mid-terms.

BARTIROMO: Marc, we going to see phase two of the tax plan (ph), you think?

LOTTER: I think they're working on it. I'm not sure if they'll get it done this year. I think there's a hope for that, but I think right now we've got to make sure that we keep what we've got going, the momentum, and if we can make it permanent, it's probably something that's better for republicans to be able to campaign on for 2018 than (ph) to actually get it done right now.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Marc, great to see you. Thanks so much.

LOTTER: Good to see you.

I mean, that's one of the biggest questions we're having on the street is that, you know, the PCE has consistently come around 1.5, you know, we'll get an outlier here and there. Otherwise, CPI is not really trudging above two. And so, I don't know where there is inflation. I haven't seen it come anywhere.

HUBBARD: Well, I think we will cross two percent in quarter PCE later this year. But I agree with you, I don't see inflation breaking out. So, I'm not one of these people worried about a sudden snap in Fed policy or indeed in a long-term rates, which would be the sum of inflation on the real rate.

BARTIROMO: Glenn, your thoughts on this deal with South Korea. It eases the steel tariffs and exchange for quotas on steel exports from South Korea. There's a provision as well to make sure not a country intentionally devalues the currency for a trade advantage. What do you make of this new deal with South Korea this morning?

HUBBARD: I don't think it's a bad deal. I think that there was a lot of uncertainty going into it because people didn't know what the administration was trying to accomplish. But I think it did make some marginal improvements for the United States. I Don't think we were even selling cars at quite our quota before, so I'm not sure what the expected gain will be. But I think it's not a bad thing. What I would urge the administration to do is be clear about what the goals are when you go in for trades, so that you don't create so much uncertainty.

KISSEL: I don't agree with that at all. I mean, we're again, we're moving back towards managed trade. We did this with Japan in the 1980s. I mean, what we did was extend protections for U.S. truck makers instead of forcing South Korea to lower their tariffs. There's no help here for our agricultural market. I mean, Glenn, this isn't expending market opportunities. This is managed trade. How is this a good deal?

HUBBARD: Well, I think it is a good deal for the sectors involved. I don't think it's the best deal that could be done. I share your views that we should move toward more openness. But given where this administration started, I'm actually pleasantly surprised.

KISSEL: Oh, so this is good from a low bar. That's what you're really saying?

HUBBARD: Well, I didn't quite say it that way.

KISSEL: OK.

MCDOWELL: If you're worried about protection policies from this White House, like, a little bit of give is a lot (INAUDIBLE).

HUBBARD: Exactly.

KISSEL: You know what? Glenn, I'm wondering if this has anything to do with South Korea and everything to do with the NAFTA negotiations that are going on that we basically strong armed South Korea into protection for certain industries so that they could pronounce a win and then go to the NAFTA partners and say, hey, look, if you don't do what we want, we're going to do what we did to South Korea. We're going to do it to you.

HUBBARD: That's possible. The Korea issue of course is complicated because it's not just the trade negotiation. It's the obvious elephant in the room of North Korea and those upcoming negotiations. So, it's really hard to see how they're connected.

BARTIROMO: Well you know, I mean, at some point and it's like, any day now. NAFTA's off the table. I mean, let's face it. They have elections in Mexico, and then we had the midterm elections here. So, by the time you're actually going to get back to the negotiating table on NAFTA is well after November. So, I don't know that we'll hear any headlines in terms of NAFTA. There's that uncertainty out there. Let me ask you about the Atlanta Fed, Glenn. Because the president of the Fed in Atlanta told the journal the tax cut and increased government spending. Like, the recently passed $1.3 trillion spending bill could put pressure on monetary policy. What's your take on that $1.3 trillion spending bill and its impact?

HUBBARD: Well, I think the spending bill was unwise. It really is a continuation of Congress's unwillingness to grasp the fiscal situation we're in. Whether it radically changes monitory policy, though, I would be a little bit more questioning. I think, the Fed will continue to gradually increase rates. The only reason it would change monetary policy is if suddenly inflation snapped, or growth snapped out of a range. I don't really see that.

BARTIROMO: We'll leave it there. Glenn, great to have you on the program.

HUBBARD: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Glenn Hubbard joining us there from Columbia. Coming up, the final meet on the fourth quarter GDP, shows growth of 2.9 percent. Stuart Varney has a thing or two to say about that, he's going to weigh in.

Then Apple takes a bite of the education market. Where the company is cutting prices on its new iPad for students. Next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(AUDIO GAP)

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria. Well, right now we're watching two names. And the first is Walgreens. Walgreens this morning right now we can see how it's trading. But they came out profit beat, sales beat, and raising the forecast. The stock is up 2.3 percent and the forecast is what's good news here for earnings. They raised this guidance for 2018 and say they continue to see growth. That's what they expect for 2018. And at least in part because of the recent acquisition of Rite Aid. Walgreens boots alliance up 2.3 percent, but it's been a real loser, and that is down 20 percent over the last 52 weeks.

Let's take a look at Apple this morning. So, Apple this morning looking down just slightly. They did have a Goldman Sachs down cutting their price target, which I'll explain in a moment. The big news is the new iPads for schools. What's happened over the last five years is that Apple has basically lost ground on the education market. Google Chrome books are huge, are up 60 percent right market share. Microsoft has in the 20 percent range and Apple has slipped. So now they're putting out this new iPad. It's going to be cheaper for the schools. Instead of 329, to be 299. It will have a stylus pen, which is only available on the highest Apple iPads. So that will be instead of 89 -- $99, it will be $89. By the way, Goldman Sachs lowered their iPhone sales forecast for the March of June quarters. Putting a new price target of 159. Much more. MORNINGS WITH MARIA coming up after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right, we got the number as we're reporting the U.S. economy grew by 2.9 percent in the fourth quarter. That is the final reading out this morning. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stuart Varney with some thoughts there. Stuart, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Am I as surprised as you, or are you as surprised as I am? Because I wasn't expecting 2.9. That's pretty close to three percent growth, originally reported I think, back in 2.5, something like that. That's a very solid rate of growth. Now, here's my surprise not just at that solid rate of growth but at the market reaction. I see interest rates as in the ten-year treasury down at 2.76 percent. Why so low? Having recently touched 2.9, why are we at 2.76 when we've just got a nice, strong report on the economy? Why did Futures go from a gain of 90 to a gain of 48?

BARTIROMO: Right.

VARNEY: How come that happened?

BARTIROMO: I'm wondering if it's this idea that rates are going to go up five times do I. I find that extraordinary, five interest rates hike this year. What do you think?

VARNEY: I suppose that's what's in the cards given the strength in the fourth quarter last year. But I'm just no good at predicting what the Fed's going to do. You know me, Maria. I don't do much on the Fed. I have a buzzer if I start running on about the Fed.

BARTIROMO: You're right, you're right.

VARNEY: If you're -- if you're really talking about five rate increases this year. If that's what they're talking about, no wonder Futures are not performing really well.

BARTIROMO: Well that, I'm just trying to come up with an explanation of why the market went from up 100 to up to 50. Because, I think you're right. This is a solid growth story. (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: Some of this is going to be end of quarter putting some lipstick on that portfolio and pulling back on these tech stocks --

BARTIROMO: Good point.

MCDOWELL: -- and reallocating to a safer asset, particularly going into a long weekend where the bond market closes midday on Thursday, I think it's closed on Friday.

BARTIROMO: Yes, stock markets are close on Friday as well.

VARNEY: Yes, the market's closed Friday. It's supposed to be three-day weekend. But you know, Dagen's right there. The focus of the market this morning is not economic growth. It's not the Fed. It's not interest rates. It's technology stocks. They're still under pressure. They are under attack starting with Facebook. And I, think that's what's doing it to the overall market.

BARTIROMO: You're right. End of quarter positioning.

MCDOWELL: Technology 25 percent of the S&P at early February that was the highest percentage it's been since the dot-com bubble blew up back in 18 years ago this month.

KELLY: Just to get to GDP, I just want to point out the fact that this is a great number before tax cuts started to take effect.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

KELLY: I mean, you had people spending money. (CROSSTALK) It was the household spending number is what led this to 2.9 percent. So, if you think about that, that's before people even got those $1,000 bonuses from the corporations. So, this is leaning toward an even better number for the Q1 here. So, I think, the market is actually trying to digest this. If we're getting these great numbers before the policies took effect, what kind of numbers are we going to get for Q1 and the rest of this year.

BARTIROMO: Good point.

VARNEY: The Trump growth agenda rolls on, does it not.

BARTIROMO: Exactly, and we got the jobs number out a week from Friday. So, let's see what that number is. And of course, first quarter earnings are going to start, Stuart, and they should be good.

VARNEY: They better be.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in about eight minutes, Stuart.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins half of the hour, right after mornings with Maria. But first, will President Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum impact the oil industry? Jeff Flock is live at the New York International Auto Show with some answers. Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: And we have news on that this morning, Maria in an interview with Scott Keogh of Audi here exclusively on the FOX Business Network this morning. I'll get to that in the moment, but first, I want to show you the most important unveil. No, it's not the Camaro Hot Wheels 50th version, I just showed you that because it's kind of fun to look at. But take a look at the what I think it's the most important unveil of the show, that is the Toyota RAV4. Why is that the most important unveil of this show? Because other than the pick-up trucks, the F150 and the Chevy's and the rest, that is the best-selling vehicle in America. They sold 400,000 of those last year. And despite the fact that it was an old version, this new version is out now. So, people love the SUVs, and I think SUVs are the star of the show this year. If you take a look at the numbers, SUV sales in the U.S. this last year up six percent. Cars down almost two percent. There you go.

Now onto the news. That is on tariffs. We talked to Scott Keogh of Audi. You know, automakers are unsettled about this. Not only the steel tariffs and the aluminum tariffs but the potential of trade war. Here is what Scott Keogh told us on FOX Business this morning about his fears about trade war. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCOTT KEOGH, PRESIDENT, AUDI: And I think a lot of this back and forth starts to put doubt into the system. You've seen the doubt a little bit with how the stock market responded and doubt is not a good thing for the business. We believe in free trade. We believe America competitiveness because when you're competitive, you have the best workers, you make the best products, and you win the day. So, that's what we believe in and, of course, the details, event flows, let's see where it goes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FLOCK: I leave you, Maria, this is the VW Atlas. They have a concept. They're about to unveil, and the rumor has it, and we are going to only say that much, they will unveil a pickup truck. A VW pickup truck concept. I talked to VW earlier. They said that's a very patriotic space, but they think maybe they can play in it. Interesting. See if they can get one that would sell, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Jeff, do you think one of the reasons for the pickup and SUV sales is the price of oil? Maybe when gasoline comes down, people feel, well, then I will go big again instead of going for the smaller, electric cars.

FLOCK: I talked to Scott Keogh, and I said what do you think? And he said you know, with fracking and everything else going on around the world, I think I'll be retired before we have $4 gas again. He doesn't plan to retire any time soon, by the way. So, FYI.

BARTIROMO: Well look, the fact (INAUDIBLE) are in New York this week, and I can tell you for sure, that they're saying $100 oil is going to look cheap in the coming years. I don't know. It feels like $100 oil is off the table with the supply coming out of the U.S. but --

KELLY: Well yes, the Saudi's are also -

FLOCK: There's going to be a lot of SUVs and trucks sitting around.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

FLOCK: If that's the case.

KELLY: Yes, the Saudis are capitulating doing a deal with the Russians on a 10 to 20 year cooperation. But, Jeff, I'm more interested in this Toyota RAV4 situation that you would brought up. The best-selling sort of mini- crossover, is there any indication why?

FLOCK: Isn't that amazing.

KELLY: Yes, is there any indication why that is? Have you gotten any color on that?

FLOCK: Well, people -- especially with the gas prices as they are and, of course, RAV4 gets pretty good mileage anyway. You know, people have just gone away from cars. There's plenty more room in these vehicles, if you've got kids, whatever you're doing, the SUVs work, you know? It's the station wagon of the new age.

MCDOWELL: Mama McDowell -- Mama McDowell, can sum up in one sentence why people buy SUVs and pickup trucks. I can see out of it that's why people buy them.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: They don't like little cars.

FLOCK: Thinking high, they like to be high.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I'm flying high and I can see -(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Rather than sitting deep into a Sevan. That's absolutely right. Jeff, thank you.

FLOCK: Like always great.

BARTIROMO: Jeff Flock at the International Auto Show in New York.

Coming up final thoughts from the officer panel. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right, final thoughts of officer panel. Kevin Kelly.

KELLY: Earning season is going to be -- do very well. It's coming up in the next couple of weeks. We'll hear from bank first. That's going to lead the rally higher.

BARTIROMO: 60 percent earnings good, (INAUDIBLE) Mary.

KISSEL: Yes that's true. And I just want to make a quick note about trade, Maria. The White House is going to come out and really try to sell this deal with South Korea. Don't buy it, they're going to talk about the trade deficit. As if it's a problem. It's not, this is not a market opening. This is managed trade, it's the wrong way to go. Sorry (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Wow, you are not liking that deal.

KISSEL: I don't.

KELLY: Kissel the missile.

MCDOWELL: And this real quickly, thank you to John Paul Stevens, former Supreme Court Justice. For actually proving to people who believe in the second amendment. That the left does want to take it away. Give me a pickup truck with a Gun Rock.

BARTIROMO: Wow, Dagen McDowell, whacking it up. All right, Dagen, Mary, great to see everybody. Thank you so much. Kevin, (INAUDIBLE) take it away.

KELLY: I will. Thanks, Maria. Crunch time the big tech. They led the market rally.

END

MARIA BARTIROMO: Hello ladies, good morning to you. Thanks so much we'll see you in a little while. Good morning everybody, thanks for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Wednesday, it is Wednesday March 28th. Your top stories right now, 6 A.M. on the East Coast. Technology taking it's toll, stocks stumble yesterday, weighed down by major technology names. Facing concerns over new regulatory scrutiny. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 344 points, down one and a half percent. Along the top loser's yesterday, Facebook, Alphabet and Apple which all turned negative for the year.

The news coming as Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agrees to testify before lawmakers on Capital Hill. Facebook down another 5 percent. Future this morning, looking like this, we're looking at weakness at the trading this morning. Dow industrial set to open down about 50 points. NASDAQ also down 45 points right now. Investors are watching for the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP that is due out at 8:30 A.M. eastern. We are expecting growth of two point seven percent. That is the economist estimate.

For Europe this morning right across the board, take a look at the European embassy's(ph) FT 100 down two thirds of one percent and the CAC cost(ph) and the DAX index both down better than 1 percent right now. In Asia over night, similar stories, steep declines across the board. Worse performers is Hong Kong, HANG SENG index down two and a half percent. The global sell off coming amid a possible crack down. Speculation is mounting that the White House is considering regulating Chinese investments in technology companies. Senator Lindsey Graham waiting on taking that action against China.

LINDSEY GRAHAM: They steal everything you bring to China, they manipulate the currency, they dump steal in a below value into the world economy and Trump said during the campaign he was going to push back. He has. And if the French and the Germans were smart, they would join President Trump to change Chinese business practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Then major implications for the sector and the markets coming up this morning. The trade deal secured, President Trump making moves, reaching an agreement with South Korea, his first deal since taking office. We are breaking down the deal as the commander in chief makes good on yet another campaign promise. And new problems to report for Tesla. The details as the National Transportation Safety Board investigates another fatal crash. The stock down (ph) another two percent this morning.

Too slow. FBI Directory Christopher Wray says he will double the number of personnel assigned to reviewing the GOP demanding documents in the investigation of the Clinton e-mail investigation, FBI abuse and the firing of Andrew McCabe. We'll tell you what's next after that subpoena got things moving. And then talk about a d'oh-nut. Springfield coming to Krispy Kreme with Simpsons themed pastries.

All that coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it this (ph) Fox Business hour is Dagen McDowell, Benchmark managing partner Kevin Kelly and the Wall Street Journal's editorial board member, Fox News contributor Mary Kissel.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, JOURNALIST, FOX BUSINESS NEWS: D'oh.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I knew she was going to do that. That's good. Thank you. Thank you so much.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: You didn't do too bad a job yourself.

BARTIROMO: OK. Hey, welcome back from -- from the wedding.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you very much. I missed you guys, but --

BARTIROMO: We missed you. Yes.

KELLY: Yes, but it worked out. I got to tear up the dance floor, you know. It was -- it was perfect.

BARTIROMO: How's the missus?

KELLY: She's doing exceptionally well. She's --

BARTIROMO: Congratulations.

KELLY: Yes. Yes. It's -- this is -- it's called perseverance, 12 years a love story in the making. I mean, it --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: 12 years.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes. Wow (ph).

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wow.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, so -- so --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He's really in love.

BARTIROMO: She's patient. She's a keeper.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, she's great.

BARTIROMO: A lot on the table this morning to discuss, you guys. We got trade, we got the market sell-off. Lot of uncertainty over there.

MARY KISSEL, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Yes, lot of uncertainty and a lot of fake news about this trade deal, too, Maria. I hope we're going to get into that. It's not exactly I think what the White House is selling.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

KISSEL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll talk about that.

MCDOWELL: And then also questions about Facebook going forward, it's profitability, how much is it worth. It's really hard to put a number on it. If you have users leaving or spending less time on the service and advertisers turning their back on Facebook, potentially. I mean, that, historically, that's really been the best way to make money over the long term in the market, is invest in good companies that are raising their dividends and there's plenty of them.

BARTIROMO: Do you worry about the current upset around trade and tariffs?

YARDENI: Well, I worry about it. I think, to the extent, that the market worries about it. I have to worry about it. I think globalization is here to stay. I think they're just too much interdependence to settle a shut off world trade. And I don't really think this administration wants to move away from free trade. I really don't have a problem with fair trade as long as it is free trade. And I think this administration is using a lot of threats to make trade fair for the United States...

BARTIROMO: Yes.

YARDENI: ...and it's working.

BARTIROMO: Let's face it, we have deficits - trade deficits...

YARDENI: Yes we do.

BARTIROMO: ...across the world.

YARDENI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Pretty significant actually. $800 billion...

YARDENI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: ...when you look at...

YARDENI: Right.

BARTIROMO: ...collectively speaking. So, in terms of their policies, then you think the markets are getting it wrong?

YARDENI: Well, I think the markets are - have, sort of, a life of their own. It's not just about the fundamentals. It's also, sometimes, about the internal working as a market. And I think we're just seeing a consolidation and some of the profit taking and, sort of, the high flyers coming back to reality about what can and can't be achieved.

So, I think once if we can solve it for a few more months, it is a good thing because then the market will mosey along with earnings.

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting 3 present economic growth this year?

YARDENI: I am. I think the frustrating thing for our economy is that all this stimulus the Administration is throwing at it, some of it does get leaked through the trade deficit and that's why there is this pressure to do something about that. But I think we could grow 3%; I don't see 4%. I don't think that demographics and productivity numbers are going to make that number work.

BARTIROMO: Not even a couple years out?

YARDENI: Not even a couple of years out. The demography is such the labor force growth is extremely slow. I mean back in the 60s, 70s and 80s, a good part of what I wrote about in my book is the baby boomers flooded in, women flooded in and we had tremendous participation rate increases. But now the baby boomers are getting older and millennials are not providing the labor force growth.

BARTIROMO: And that is why the participation rate is where it is?

YARDENI: That's correct.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Ed, it's great to see you. Thanks so much. Congrats on the book. Check it out. Ed Yardeni.

Coming up, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu under orders to rest after going to the hospital with flu-like symptoms. We're told he is okay and resting right now. Then find out the gross reason for delay of game at Dodger Stadium last night. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A tough day yesterday. Thousands mourn in honor, a New York City firefighter killed on a movie set. Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Good morning Maria. It was really was an inspiring and emotional show of from the New York Fire Department along with friends, family, and firefighters from around the country that attended the funeral service for Lieutenant Michael Davison at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue. The 37 year old father of four young children died after fighting flames in a building in Harlem that was being used as a movie set for a film called "Motherless Brooklyn." Meanwhile a tenant in the building is now suing after Edward Norton's production company for $7 million. The tenant claiming she suffered severe permanent personal injuries because of the film company's negligence.

Another headline we're following for you this morning, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is reportedly feeling better after he was hospitalized. Netanyahu had a high fever and cough after not taking enough time to recover from a prior throat infection. He tweeted out yesterday that he was on his way home from the hospital to get some rest.

Well the Mega Millions Jackpot grew into a whopping $502 million, after no one won last night. This is the fourth largest jackpot in Mega Millions history. The next drawing is going to be Friday night and your chances of winning, just you know 258.9 million in 1. Yes, so good luck with that.

All right, the classic sitcom "Rosanne" is back on TV after 21 years and this time the title character played by Roseanne Barr supports President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO)

JACKIE HARRIS, SISTER OF ROSEANNE BARR: How could you have voted for him Roseanne?

ROSEANNE BARR: He talked about jobs, Jackie. He said he'd shake things up. I mean this might come as a complete shock to you, but we almost lost our house the way things are going.

HARRIS: Have you looked at the news because now things are worse.

BARR: Not on the real news.

(END VIDEO)

CASONE: Roseanne Barr herself is a Trump supporter. The nine-episode season started last night. John Goodman has returned as Dan, Roseanne Conner's husband and along with daughter Darlene, played by Sara Gilbert, who is now an executive producer on the show. They explained Dan's death by saying oh, it was all a dream. By the way, Dan is alive, never mind.

BARTIROMO: Yes and of course she has been trashed on twitter as a result of her support for Donald Trump.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wait. You got into a twitter fight with Roseanne, didn't you?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: No, no, I am a fan. It is great the show is back. I think that, you know look, a lot of mainstream America is not represented on television. And you know what? All sorts of people voted for Donald Trump and I think it's very savvy of Roseanne to bring this character back right now.

MCDOWELL: And it's both sides that are portrayed, it's the right and the left. It's the conversations that people actually have in their homes. And she was -- Roseanne was a trailblazer when she started in terms of her stand up and doing the show. So I've got to sit down and watch it.

BARTIROMO: You're right. It's a conversation happening across...

MCDOWELL: Whitney Cummings, who is a female comedian also is working on it as one of the writers, and I know that was like - because I follow her on Instagram. I know that that's an important addition to the cast or the writing staff.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE : I was just going to say that Tim Allen had a great show that represented the right and got canceled and it was on ABC. It had great ratings.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. Why did it get canceled?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: "Home Improvement?"

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No, no, no. It was called "Last Man Standing." It got canceled - it got cancelled for nebulous reasons, no one really knows but it had great ratings.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a break. When we come back, the biggest winner in this year's March Madness, Sister Jean, the 98-year-old spiritual leader of Loyola Chicago men's basketball team just made Bobblehead history.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. YouTube TV will be the first ever presenting sponsor for the NBA finals. This as (ph) Nike extends its contract with the NFL. Lauren Simonetti was (ph) told the details in sports this morning, Laura.

LAURA SIMONETTI, SPORTS: (SPORTS)

BARITROMO: Laura thank you.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

BARTIROMO: (Inaudible) we'll see you a little Lauren Simonetti. Still ahead, we are live from the New York auto show. Wait until you see what's there. We talk about what's driving Ford Motor Company in the future.

I'm going to check in on those autonomous cars post that accident. Next up, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5S01-3W51-DXH2-64DG-00000-00The Team Discuss Chinese Tariffs; FBI Investigation Continues2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:35:09ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTHarry Kazianis, Mary Kissel, Cheryl Casone, Edward YardeniNEWSFinancial032801cb.231The Team Discuss Chinese Tariffs; FBI Investigation ContinuesMaria Bartiromo, Dagan McDowell

MARIA BARTIROMO: Hello ladies, good morning to you. Thanks so much we'll see you in a little while. Good morning everybody, thanks for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Wednesday, it is Wednesday March 28th. Your top stories right now, 6 A.M. on the East Coast. Technology taking it's toll, stocks stumble yesterday, weighed down by major technology names. Facing concerns over new regulatory scrutiny. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 344 points, down one and a half percent. Along the top loser's yesterday, Facebook, Alphabet and Apple which all turned negative for the year.

The news coming as Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly agrees to testify before lawmakers on Capital Hill. Facebook down another 5 percent. Future this morning, looking like this, we're looking at weakness at the trading this morning. Dow industrial set to open down about 50 points. NASDAQ also down 45 points right now. Investors are watching for the final reading of the fourth quarter GDP that is due out at 8:30 A.M. eastern. We are expecting growth of two point seven percent. That is the economist estimate.

For Europe this morning right across the board, take a look at the European embassy's(ph) FT 100 down two thirds of one percent and the CAC cost(ph) and the DAX index both down better than 1 percent right now. In Asia over night, similar stories, steep declines across the board. Worse performers is Hong Kong, HANG SENG index down two and a half percent. The global sell off coming amid a possible crack down. Speculation is mounting that the White House is considering regulating Chinese investments in technology companies. Senator Lindsey Graham waiting on taking that action against China.

LINDSEY GRAHAM: They steal everything you bring to China, they manipulate the currency, they dump steal in a below value into the world economy and Trump said during the campaign he was going to push back. He has. And if the French and the Germans were smart, they would join President Trump to change Chinese business practices.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Then major implications for the sector and the markets coming up this morning. The trade deal secured, President Trump making moves, reaching an agreement with South Korea, his first deal since taking office. We are breaking down the deal as the commander in chief makes good on yet another campaign promise. And new problems to report for Tesla. The details as the National Transportation Safety Board investigates another fatal crash. The stock down (ph) another two percent this morning.

Too slow. FBI Directory Christopher Wray says he will double the number of personnel assigned to reviewing the GOP demanding documents in the investigation of the Clinton e-mail investigation, FBI abuse and the firing of Andrew McCabe. We'll tell you what's next after that subpoena got things moving. And then talk about a d'oh-nut. Springfield coming to Krispy Kreme with Simpsons themed pastries.

All that coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it this (ph) Fox Business hour is Dagen McDowell, Benchmark managing partner Kevin Kelly and the Wall Street Journal's editorial board member, Fox News contributor Mary Kissel.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, JOURNALIST, FOX BUSINESS NEWS: D'oh.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I knew she was going to do that. That's good. Thank you. Thank you so much.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: You didn't do too bad a job yourself.

BARTIROMO: OK. Hey, welcome back from -- from the wedding.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Thank you very much. I missed you guys, but --

BARTIROMO: We missed you. Yes.

KELLY: Yes, but it worked out. I got to tear up the dance floor, you know. It was -- it was perfect.

BARTIROMO: How's the missus?

KELLY: She's doing exceptionally well. She's --

BARTIROMO: Congratulations.

KELLY: Yes. Yes. It's -- this is -- it's called perseverance, 12 years a love story in the making. I mean, it --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: 12 years.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes. Wow (ph).

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wow.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, so -- so --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He's really in love.

BARTIROMO: She's patient. She's a keeper.

KELLY: Yes. Yes, she's great.

BARTIROMO: A lot on the table this morning to discuss, you guys. We got trade, we got the market sell-off. Lot of uncertainty over there.

MARY KISSEL, EDITORIAL BOARD MEMBER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Yes, lot of uncertainty and a lot of fake news about this trade deal, too, Maria. I hope we're going to get into that. It's not exactly I think what the White House is selling.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

KISSEL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll talk about that.

MCDOWELL: And then also questions about Facebook going forward, it's profitability, how much is it worth. It's really hard to put a number on it. If you have users leaving or spending less time on the service and advertisers turning their back on Facebook, potentially. Again, that's a big question mark and it's certainly weighing on the broad market.

BARTIROMO: This is -- this is the real first test that we've seen for this company in terms -- you're right, valuation, but also the sustainability, if people are worried about user data.

KELLY: They -- they really --

MCDOWELL: Mark -- Mark -- Mark Zuckerberg didn't invent anything. We kept playing that sound bite from Steve Jobs. He didn't invent anything, just preyed on our desire to be liked. It's a -- it's an advertising vehicle. He just did a better job than Classmates and Tripod and Geocities. I date myself, but thank god I am close to 50, because I actually remember a lot of these companies that tried to do what Facebook did.

It's at 2 billion users. How much bigger can it get?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: If (ph) those people spend less time on that service, those -- those earnings are going to be a lot lower than people think.

BARTIROMO: And boy, did investors react yesterday. That is our top story right now, the technology sector taking a beating. A steep sell-off in tech stocks yesterday pulled U.S. markets sharply lower with the DOW closing down nearly 400-points. One day after the indices posted their best day in more than two years. Technology stock has come under pressure amid concerns over increased government scrutiny in the wake of privacy questions surrounding Facebook.

All this coming amid speculation that the Trump administration is considering a crackdown on Chinese investments in U.S. technologies by using a law reserved for national emergencies. Joining us now to weigh in is director of defense studies at the Center for National Interest and the executive editor of National Interest Magazine, Harry Kazianis. Good to see you, Harry. Thanks very much for joining us.

HARRY KAZIANIS, DIRECTOR OF DEFENSE STUDIES, CENTER FOR NATIONAL INTEREST: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So let's start first with the crackdown on Chinese investments in technology. We know that China has participated in 10 percent off venture deals in the U.S. in the last five years. Your take on what could happen in terms of China investing in U.S. companies.

KAZIANIS: Maria, I think there being some sort of restrictions is a very practical and an important step. I think if we look at the history of Chinese actions, really over the last 10 years and things they've done to the United States, not just economic but geopolitical, there had to be some restrictions. You know, being in the defense sector, looking at this from that perspective, we look at some of the things the Chinese done in terms of stealing a lot of our defense intellectual property.

They've hacked in and stolen our aircraft carrier designs, the V-22 Osprey, the F-35, which is a trillion dollar defense program. So when you look at it from that perspective, there has to be some restrictions. And then we talk about the technology of the future, things like 5G, A.I. If Chinese companies were to come in and essentially, you know, buy parts of U.S. companies or get into joint ventures and then take that technology, we're essentially giving away our economic future to China. And I think that would be a big mistake.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, I know that we have CFIUS, Mary, and that really does regulate the -- whether or not we should see ownership of American companies. But at the same time, China has such strict situations with regard to American investing there. And we don't have anything like that.

KISSEL: No, I mean look, our tariff barriers are very low compared to China. And China also has a lot of barriers that are not set in stone or formalized, right? They -- they say well, you know, if you come here and you really want to get in, you have to give us 51 percent control and we to have a communist party member on your board in China, things like that.

So Harry's absolutely right. There are a lot of problems here. Harry, my question to you is what is strategic? You know, I understand that we don't want investment in dual use technologies, defense, certain telecommunication industries, but where else does this go? Does it go to energy companies? I mean, what's the limit here?

KAZIANIS: I think the thing that I worry about most, Mary, is technologies of the future. Like I was saying, 5G could be a revolutionary technology. I mean, most of us at home are getting -- you know, on our internet speeds, about 100, 150 megs per second. That is the speeds of -- of 5G over cellular networks. That could be revolutionary in terms of self driving cars, medical devices.

And in terms of, you know, strategy and -- and overall geopolitics and intelligence, if the Chinese were to gain footholds in those arenas, the amount of intelligence they could gather would be astronomical. Now, I don't want to sound like I'm panicking over, you know, what the Chinese can do in terms of intelligence capabilities, but I think we have some very real concerns when you combine that, in terms of all of the geopolitical things the Chinese have done over 10 years.

So I think it's good to be cautious, I think it's something that we have to do. But we have to remember, the U.S. China relationship is changing, really since the fall of the Soviet Union in1991. This relationship was begging to be changed. I mean, one of the reasons why America and China actually came together in the first place is because of the Soviet Union.

When the Soviet Union collapsed, there was always going to be some sort of inevitable change, but it was always economics that brought us together. Now it's actually --

BARTIROMO: Just want to (ph) point out, Kevin, one -- one thing that Devin Nunes told me on Sunday is not only are we dealing with these economic issues with China, but right now, they're buying up a lot of infrastructure across the world. They're investing in these countries and then getting a sealine position and setting up military bases right there. This is another thing that this administration is watching over (ph).

KELLY: Yes, especially in Africa, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly.

KELLY: In -- in -- in Djibouti. And I think one of the --

BARTIROMO: Right.

KELLY: -- important things to note is that China is going to get this 5G technology whether we like it or not, right? And one of the -- the things this administration has done is block the Broadcom deal with Qualcomm. The issue actually has to do with will we have that infrastructure, that technology? Are we going to have access to it in times of national defense? And I think that's the biggest -- biggest question.

If -- if we don't have access to it and only the Chinese do, if they're scooping up U.S. companies, that's the biggest issue. But I think the -- I think one of the things we're tiptoeing around is North Korea. I mean, China is completely enabling North Korea and a lot of their weaponized attacks across the world, whether it's in South Korea, here.

So the only way North Korea survives and thrives is through China. Now, do you think that's one of the biggest conflicts of interest that we're having right now with China and their technology? Harry?

KAZIANI: I do. I do. And I -- and I think the -- the point on North Korea is so key here. I mean, no wonder the -- you know -- Kim Jung-un is going to, you know, meet with Xi Jinping so early, in terms of having multiple different summits and whatnot. And I think when we talk about issues on the Korean Peninsula and how this all comes to play, I think it's extremely important for the United States to continue making sure that we apply maximum pressure on both of those countries.

Because there's a relationship where essentially North Korea feeds off China, but China also feeds off North Korea. And I think as long as we're ensuring that pressure on both sides is being maintained, I think that's the smartest way to go. So I -- I think all of these situations we're talking about, the recalibrating of the U.S. China relationship, North Korea, it's all one big pot that we have to worry about.

MCDOWELL: We always talk about the big picture in terms of the U.S. and China and China's investment in technologies. There's a story in the Wall Street Journal that pinpoints how it does effect mama and daddy, if you will, in -- in rural parts of America.

And a lot of smaller telecomm companies have relied on gear made by Huawei, the bigger company since 2012 because there was a fear -- there was a congressional report done -- there was a fear that China would exploit that technology being in the United States in order to spy or even hack into our data networks.

But smaller telecomm companies have relied on that very gear because it's cheaper. And there was an -- the FCC put out a proposal on Monday that might -- that will likely restrict these smaller companies drawing on this $8.5 billion government-run fund to build out these rural networks. So again, there are broad implications for these rules that are sent out of Washington.

BARTIROMO: And -- and the administration is watching each of these nuances. Meanwhile, we've got to talk about this. The state media has reported -- the Chinese state new media reporting that North Korean leader Kim Jong-un did in fact make a surprise visit to Beijing to meet with President Xi Jinping.

The North Korean leader reportedly told his Chinese counterpart that Pyongyang is committed to denuclearization, and is willing to talk to U.S. officials. President Trump just tweeted about this moments ago, want to get this tweet out right away.

Here's what the president just said, for years and through many administrations, everyone said that peace and the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula was not even a small possibility.

Now there is a good chance that Kim Jong-un will do what is right for his people and for humanity. Look forward to our meeting. And of course, we know that the president is planning on meeting the head of the North Korea in may, Harry, do you -- do we know what Kim Jong-un would want in exchange for potentially giving up his nuclear weapons?

Do we believe that he even would consider such a thing?

KAZIANIS: Well Maria, that's the golden question in this whole situation. What does Kim Jong-un want? I think at a bare minimum, he's going to want some sort of peace treaty to formally end the Korean War, some sort of diplomatic recognition by the United States, potentially as much as hundreds of billions of dollars in economic assistance.

That might be one of the reasons he actually went to China. He -- he is going to demand a lot, but we're also going to demand a lot. We're going to need to have really tough inspections to go in and make sure the North Koreans are actually living up to the deal.

But (ph) even gets worse, I mean do they give up their chemical weapons or missiles? We have a lot of questions this morning and not a lot of answers.
